ranked_diseases.explanation: Classic presentation with congenital sensorineural hearing loss and delayed speech/language development. Most common syndromic cause of hearing loss.
Presents with congenital profound sensorineural hearing loss and delayed motor/speech milestones. Would need ophthalmologic evaluation to confirm.
Can present with sensorineural hearing loss and secondary speech delays. Would typically have additional features like heterochromia or white forelock.
Similar to Type 1 but without dystopia canthorum. Hearing loss is the primary feature with secondary speech delays.
Presents with congenital profound sensorineural deafness and speech delays. Associated with long QT syndrome - cardiac evaluation needed.
Can present with sensorineural or mixed hearing loss and speech delays. Would typically have branchial or renal anomalies.
Can include sensorineural hearing loss and developmental delays. Would expect multiple other anomalies (coloboma, choanal atresia, etc.).
Progressive sensorineural hearing loss can occur, though typically later onset. Would need renal and ophthalmologic evaluation.
